awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Community-Building Platform That Uses Machine Learning To Facilitate In-Person Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the reinvention of community wellness programming from a typically qualitative process into an evidence-based procedure. Treating wellness as a science will allow for more efficacious use of wellness budgets (an annual expenditure exceeding $100 Billion), will create a positive social impact within organizations, and by extension, society as a whole. Organizations with effective wellness initiatives have higher employee engagement, improved productivity, and increased profitability. Hence, there is significant opportunity for societal and commercial impact through evidence-based wellness technologies.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project involves the theoretical development, and practical deployment, of recommendation algorithms that arrange meetings between groups of people with divergent interests and incentives. Our research objectives are (1) the development of a theoretically grounded recommendation algorithm that accounts for the effects of social dynamics and incentives on behavior, (2) the development of an application to facilitate community wellness through in-person meetings.  We anticipate the successful deployment of the platform, the collection of multi-center data for semi-supervised training and prospective evaluation of the developed algorithms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our Phase I activities were structured around the development of a recommendation engine and a host application that were tested for their ability to make a measurable impact on community wellness goals. During Phase I, we successfully developed a web platform, recommendation engine, and a data ecosystem; these development activities were essential to prepare the technology for autonomous, secure and reliable expansion. Using our developed technology, we studied how algorithmically-arranged meetings between groups of people with divergent backgrounds and incentives impacted their sense of belonging and cohesion. We tested our system at a major American university over a one-year period; we found significant evidence that meetings arranged by our recommendation engine improved student belonging and cohesion after one year, and that our algorithm was able to learn the specific attributes of the meetings that promoted these outcomes. These results are particularly powerful when we consider that the introductions made by our recommendation engine were only a small part of the users' larger social lives. The ability of our recommendation algorithm to measurably improve community outcomes validates the technical feasibility of the innovation, its commercial potential as a tool for organizations, and its ability to create a positive broader impact on society that is evidence-based.

 


Last Modified: 02/02/2020
Modified by: Mohammad M Ghassemi
